prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N2H+ 3-2 in LkCa 15/ GM Aur
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe N2H+, DCO+, and H2CO/CH3OH in the disks of LkCa 15 and GM Aur

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
DCO+ (Mathew et a. 2013, A&A, 557, 132) and H2CO/CH3OH (Qi et al. 2013a) are believed to be chemical related to the CO freezeout in disks. We are able to observe these lines in the same spectral setting to help constrain the CO snow line.
Due to the fact that the gas kinematics are Keplerian, effective improved resolution can be achieved by examining the spectrally resolved visibilities in each channel. Both disks are estimated to be inclined about 50 degrees, so the disk emission seen in projected velocity channel maps can be used to constrain the size of the inner radii of N2H+ ring within a few AUs, far more precisely than is affored by the limited beam size of 0.3". That's why we need a spectral resolution of 0.13-0.15 km/s.

The CO snow lines for these 2 disks are expected to be around 40-60 AU. The Source distance is about 140 pc. So we request a resolution of 0.3" so we have at least 2-3 beams over the inner edge of the ring. The largest angular scale is about 1.5-2.5" (Oberg et al. 2010).

We expect to have 40-70 beams (0.3" beam) over the N2H+ emission area and the integrated intensities are about 0.7-1.4 Jy km/s for these two disks (DISCS, Oberg et al. 2010). We will need 0.1-0.2 km/s spectral resolution to resolve the velocity structure for further visbility analysis to constrain the inner radii of the N2H+ ring. The FWHM of the line is expected to be 5 km/s. To achieve 3 sigma detection per 0.15 km/s channel for an integrated intensity of 0.017-0.019 jy/beam km/s, we request for an rms of 6 mJy/beam in a channel of 0.15 km/s wide. High SNR continuum emission can be used to selfCal and improve the line image quality.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N2H+ 3-2 in DM Tau
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observing N2H+, DCO+ and H2CO/CH3OH in the disk of DM Tau

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
DCO+ (Mathews et al. 2013) and H2CO/CH3OH (Qi et al. 2013a) are believed to be chemically related to the CO freezeout in disks. We are able to observe these lines in the same spectral setting to help constrain the CO snow line.
Due to the fact that the gas kinematics are Keplerian, effective improved resolution can be achieved by examining the spectrally resolved isibilities in each channel. Due to inclined disk, the disk emission seen in projected velocity channel maps can be used to constrain the size of the inner radii of N2H+ ring within a few AUs, far more precisely than is afforded by the limited beam size. That's why we need a spectral resolution of 0.13-0.15 km/s.

The CO snow line is expected to be around 40 AU. The source distance is about 140 pc. So we request a resolution of 0.2", so we have at least 2-3 beams across the inner edge of the ring. The largest angular scale is about 1.5" (Oberg et al. 2010).

We expect to have 60 beams over the entire N2H+ emission area of DM Tau disk and the integrated intensity is 0.97 Jy km/s according to DISCS measurement (Oberg et al. 2010). We will need 0.1-0.2 km/s spectral resolution to resolve the velocity structure. The FWHM of the line is expected to be around 5 km/s. To achieve 3 sigma detection per 0.15 km/s channel with an integrated intensity of 0.016 Jy/beam km/s, we request for an rms of 7 mJy/beam in a channel of 0.15 km/s wide. High SNR continuum emission can be used to self-cal and improve the line image quality.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N2H+ 3-2 in IM Lup
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observing N2H+, DCO+ and H2CO/CH3OH in the disk of IM Lup

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
DCO+ (Mathews et al. 2013) and H2CO/CH3OH (Qi et al. 2013a) are expected to be chemically related to the CO freezeout in disks. We are able to observe these lines in the same spectral setting to help constrain the CO snow line.
Due to the fact that the gas kinematics are Keplerian, effective improved resolution can be achieved by examining the spectrally resolved visbilitites in each channel. The disk emission seen in projected velocity channel maps can be used to constrain the size of the inner edge of N2H+ ring within a few AUs, far more precisely than is afforded by the limited beam size. That's why we need a spectral resolution of 0.13-0.15 km/s.

The CO snow line for IM Lup disk is expected to be similar to that of TW Hya around 30 AU. The source distance is about 150 pc. So we request a resolution of 0.3", so we have at least 2-3 beams accross the inner edge of N2H+ ring. The largest angular scale is about 2.5" (Oberg et al. 2011)

We expect to have 70 beams (0.3" beam) over the N2H+ emission area in the IMLup disk and the integrated intensity is about 1.59 Jy km/s (Oberg et al. 2011). We will need 0.1-0.2 km/s spectral resolution to resolve the velocity structure for further visibility analysis. The FWHM of the line is expected to be 5 km/s. To achieve 3 sigma detection per 0.15 km/s channel for an integrated intensity of 0.022 Jy/beam km/s, we request for an rms of 8.5 mJy/beam in a channel of 0.15 km/s wide. High SNR continuum emission can be used to self-cal and improve the line image quality.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N2H+ 3-2 in AS 209
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To observe N2H+, DCO+ and H2CO/CH3OH in the disk of AS 209

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
DCO+ (Mathews et al. 2013) and H2CO/CH3OH (Qi et al. 2013a) are expected to be chemically related to the CO freezeout in disks. We are able to observe these lines in the same spectral setting to help constrain the CO snow line,
Due to the fact that the gas kinematics are Keplerian, effective improved resolution can be achieved by exmaining the spectrally resolved visibilities in each channle. The AS 209 disk is inclined about 40 degrees, and the disk emission seen in projected velocity channel maps can be used to constrain the size of the inner radii of N2H+ ring within a few AUs, far more precisely than is afforded by the limited beam size of 0.3". That's why we need a spectral resolutio of 0.13-0.15 km/s.

The CO snow line is expected to be around 30 AU. The source distance is about 125 pc. So we request a resolution of 0.3", so we have at least 2-3 beams across the inner edge of the N2H+ ring. The largest angular scale is about 1.8" (Oberg et al. 2011).

We expect to have 30 beams (0.3" beam) over the N2H+ emission area in the disk of AS 209 and the integrated intensity is about 0.55 Jy km/s (Oberg et al. 2011). We will need 0.1-0.2 km/s spectral resolution to resolve the velocity structure for further visibility analysis. The FWHM of the line is expected to be 4 km/s. To achieve 3 sigma detection per 0.15 km/s channel for an integrated intensity of 0.017 Jy/beam km/s, we request for an rms of 7.5 mJy/beam in the channel of 0.15 km/s wide. High SNR continuum emission can be used to self-cal and improve the line image quality.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N2H+ in V4046 Sgr
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To observe N2H+, DCO+ and H2CO/CH3OH in the disk of V4046 Sgr.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
DCO+ (Mathews et al. 2013) and H2CO/CH3OH (Qi et al. 2013a) are expected to be chemically related to the CO freezeout in disks. We are able to observe these lines in the same spectral setting to help constrain the CO snow line.
Due to the fact that the gas kinematics are Keplerian, effective improved resolution can be achieved by examining the spectrally resolved visibilities in each channel. The V4046 Sgr disk is inclined about 30 deg and the disk emission seen in projected velocity channel maps can be used to constrain the size of the inner radii of N2H+ ring within a few AUs, far more precisely than is afforded by the limited beam size. That's why we need a spectral resolution of 0.13-0.15 km/s.

The CO snow line is expected to be around 40-60 AU. The source distance is about 73 pc, so we request a resolution of 0.4", so we can have 2-3 beams accross the inner edge of the ring. The largest angular scale is about 3" (Oberg et al. 2011).

We expect to have 56 beams over the entire N2H+ emission area in the disk around V4046 Sgr and the integrated intensity is 2.58 Jy km/s (Oberg et al. 2011). We will need 0.1-0.2 km/s spectral resolution to resolve the velocity structure for further visibility analysis. The FWHM of the line is expected to be 4 km/s. To achieve 5 sigma detection per 0.15 km/s channel for an integrated intensity 0.046 Jy/beam km/s, we request for an rms of 10 mJy/beam in a channel of 0.15 km/s wide. High SNR continuum emission can be used to self-cal and improve the line image quality.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Snow lines, or condensation fronts, of major volatiles in protoplanetary disks are proposed to regulate planet formation efficiencies as well as planet and planetesimal (comet) bulk compositions. Observational constraints on the location of major snow lines in disks are key to anchor models of planet formation, to constrain the orgins of chemical and physical structures in our Solar System and in exo-planetary systems. Recent Cycle 0 and 1 ALMA observations have demonstrated that high spectral and spatial observations of N2H+ emission enable direct imaging of the CO snow line location in protoplanetary disks. We propose to use this powerful chemical tool to survey the CO snow line radii in a sample of disks around Sun-like stars - Solar Nebula analogues, and probe the response of the CO snow line location to the stellar and disk characteristics (stellar age, incident radiation field, and cavity size), which should regulate the bulk elemental composition of planets and planetesimals formed in the disks.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.00864.S: The CO snow line and temperature structure of the HL Tau disk; PI: C Qi . 2015.1.00649.S: A survey of CO snow lines in low mass protoplanetary disks; PI: K. Schwarz.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00681.S: Locating the CO Snow Line in Protoplanetary Disks; PI: C Qi 2013.1.00583.S: Survey of CO Snow Lines in Protoplanetary Disks; PI: C Qi
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
